Posts.Title: R1 R2 for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi jsj.  Sorry to hear your diagnosis.   I had a lumpectomy 3 months ago and have been wearing non-wired crop tops ever since. I find them really comfortable, they give support and are soft against the skin. A well known High Street store sells a pack of 2 for £14. I also wore tops that opened down the front for the first couple of weeks as they were easy to get on and off when I didn't have full movement in my arm. Hope your treatment goes well. You will find this site really useful if you have any more questions. Margaret x
Posts.Title: Recommendations on bras/ post op tops.

Posts.Content: Hi Phaedra I, like you, was not happy about taking bisphosphonates because of the side effects you mention.  I did take them for 5 weeks then told my GP that I would rather not continue with them.  His offered alternatives but said that, at the end of the day, being healthy is about being happy and if I was not happy taking them then he understood my decision. I am doing lots of bone strengthening exercise and if my next DEXA scan shows further bone density loss I might think again. I have a 10% chance of a severe fracture so think I will be very careful in this icy weather! Hope you can  make a decision that is right for you. Margaret x
Posts.Title: Anyone refused to take bisphosphonates?

Posts.Content: I am lucky to live only a couple of miles from Breast Cancer Haven Wessex which is in Titchfield, Hampshire.  They offer all kinds of support and offer 10 hours of holistic therapies tailored to your needs, free of charge.  They can offer nutrition advice and have a herbalist who can make up creams if your skin reacts to radiotherapy.  They also run yoga and Pilates classes. A wonderful resource to have on my doorstep and ladies travel many miles to use it. Margaret x
